title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
text:
‚û°Ô∏è I have detailed my projects related to open science and DEI on the Committments page.



 Project website: https://fishtooluse.com
 Project instagram: https://www.instagram.com/fishtooluse/
I have been conducting a project on anvil use by fishes with Professor Culum Brown at the Fish Lab at Macquarie University (Sydney, Australia) since October 2022. It feels like an achievement to finally work on coral reef fish behaviour ‚Äì my long-term goal ‚Äì with the world expert on fish behaviour and cognition!
Almost nothing was known about this tool-use behaviour, so I have been collected observations using fieldwork and community science. We want to get basic knowledge of this behaviour, in addition to understand its evolutionary history and adaptive function. We also believe anvil use in fish is a good system for understanding the cognitive, ecological and morphological factors driving the evolution of tool use in animals.

We have a side project on social learning of tool use in a wrasse fish species, in collaboration with a team in New-Zealand. Cyndi-Lee Harrison-Burgess conducted a lab experiment during her master‚Äôs internship and found promising evidence of social learning!
So far, I have published one paper on a subset of observations in a group of fish called the New World Halichoeres (PDF available here). More papers are coming!



I am currently writing an opinion piece on transgenerational plasticity. I keep seeing the same confusions around terms and the same two mistakes in lab experiment designs when peer-reviewing papers. Feel free to reach out if you would like to get involved!





A team has been faster than me at publishing a paper about the confusion around terms. However, they did not cover everything I want to bring forward in my article ‚Äì so stay tuned!

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: ü¶à Migration patterns of Port-Jackson sharks  Side project
text:
ü¶à Migration patterns of Port-Jackson sharks  Side project
I was fortunate to be involved in Lo√©va Martin-Podevin‚Äôs master‚Äôs project, helping with data analysis and manuscript drafting. Her task was to examine the migration patterns of Port-Jackson sharks along the southeastern coast of Australia using acoustic tag data, part of a long-term project at the Fish Lab.






Check the PDF here for more details on her findings.

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: üê† Welfare housing of Betta fish  Side project
text:
üê† Welfare housing of Betta fish  Side project
It was a real pleasure working remotely with Naomi Clark-Shen to analyse her data on the behaviour of Siamese fighting Betta fish. Special thanks to Culum Brown for connecting us! Betta fish are among the most popular pet fish in the world, yet they are often housed in tiny, inadequate jars. By carefully monitoring their behaviour, she was able to show that better housing is needed for their welfare.





Check the PDF here to learn more, including advice for Betta fish care.

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
text:
üêå Characterising transgenerational plasticity  PhD project
Some people say that you will eventually circle back to your PhD project at some point of your career, though I think it‚Äôs unlikely since I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs behind me! This is probably because I had always wanted to work on fish behaviour and evolution, which I did end up doing for my PhD project. That said, I had two great supervisors ‚Äì √âmilien Luquet and Sandrine Pl√©net ‚Äì with whom I always enjoy interacting, as I do with everyone in the LEHNA team.
I began my PhD project at Claude Bernard Lyon 1 University (France) with a 3-month internship in 2015 and officially started in September 2017. I completed it in April 2021. During this time, I conducted two lab experiments on tiny, cute freshwater snails over multiple generations, analysed three datasets from previous experiments, and wrote a literature review (PDF)!
The lab experiments followed a similar a similar design: We were exposing snails to predator odours and then measuring the resulting effects on their shell morphology and behaviour, along with transgenerational effects on their offspring. We repeated this experiment to identify factors influencing the presence, magnitude and direction of these transgenerational effects. The factors we characterised included the generation that was exposed (PDF), the parent exposed (PDF) and the timing of exposure during development (PDF). In the background, there was the aim of understanding how different environmental effects combine to shape the expression of anti-predator defences (PDF). My PhD thesis is available for download (here), though it‚Äôs written in French!





I was proud to apply my interest in and knowledge of animal personality to a project that examined whether parental exposure to predators caused snails to behave more similarly to or differently from one another (PDF). I also became involved in two side projects, both of which focused on transgenerational plasticity in Physa snails, of course! One explored the transgenerational effects at the level of gene expression (PDF); while the other investigated the maintenance of transgenerational plasticity after many lab generations, which is still waiting in √âmilien‚Äôs computer.
As you may have noticed, four papers ended up being published in 2020, people often get confused when citing Tariel et al.¬†2020 ‚Äì which I completely understand! ü§™

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: ‚ù§Ô∏è Mate copying in fish  Master internship
text:
‚ù§Ô∏è Mate copying in fish  Master internship
Sabine N√∂bel needed students to conduct experiments for her project, and here I came! She aimed to determine whether female mosquitofish and zebrafish copy the mate choice of other females, and whether their mate-copying capacity was linked to their personalities. I spent over 3 months at the Laboratoire Evolution et Diversit√© Biologique, at Paul Sabatier Toulouse III University (France), working under the supervision of Sabine and Etienne Danchin. You can find the results for both species in these publications: mosquitofish PDF, zebrafish PDF.

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: üêü Transgenerational plasticity on personality  Master internship
text:
üêü Transgenerational plasticity on personality  Master internship
I cannot recommend this lab highly enough, where everyone is kind, down-to-earth, and excellent at research! This includes my two supervisors, Bart Adriaenssens and Neil Metcalfe, who supported me during my three-month internship in 2016 at the Institute of Biodiversity, Animal Health & Comparative Medicine at University of Glasgow (United Kingdow).






During the internship, I got to design my first-ever experiment from scratch to automatically track stickleback positions. Apart from the cameras, I built the entire experiment from bits, leftovers, and pieces I found in the gigantic university basement: it felt like a treasure hunt! I still need to publish this study ‚Äì the data is sadly sitting on my computer.

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: üê£ Brood parasistim in fish  Master internship
text:
üê£ Brood parasistim in fish  Master internship
In Spring 2015, I had the privilege to meet and work with one of my favourite researchers, Giacomo Bernardi  at the University of California, Santa Cruz (USA). I conducted molecular biology lab work in his lab near the sea, where the weather was a perfectly sunny 20-25¬∞C every day.
There are only a handful of marine fish species that care for their newborn babies (though many care for their eggs), and two Altrichthys damselfish species are one of them. These fish stay with their babies in the same spot on the reef and ferociously protect them ‚Äì and you know how bold and fierce a damselfish can be! Giacomo wanted to determine whether brood parasitism occurred in these species. Since the babies look very similar to each other, even between the two Altrichthys species, we used microsatellite DNA markers to determine whether parents were caring exclusively for their own offspring or for babies from other parents as well. Long story short, there was indeed brood parasitism! You can find more information in the PDF.





To keep me busy at the end of my internship, Giacomo had me prepare samples for RAD sequencing, which resulted in two great publications.

title: JTA‚Äôs scientific projects
section: üî• Recolonization processes of gorgonians  Bachelor internship
text:
üî• Recolonization processes of gorgonians  Bachelor internship
My first research internship took place in a dream location: Marseille, during the summer of 2014, in a station less than a minute‚Äôs walk from a small beach and just a 15-minute bike ride from the ‚ÄòVieux Port‚Äô city centre. I worked at the Endoume station of the IMBE (Institut M√©diterran√©en de la Biodiversit√© et d‚Äô√âcologie marine et continentale), which is part of Aix-Marseille University. I worked one and a half months at the station under the supervision of Didier Aurelle, whom I recommend highly as a supervisor.





The project focused on the recolonisation abilities of gorgonian corals, either on a new shipwreck or following mortality events caused by heat waves. We assessed this using microsatellite markers (PDF)

title: Personal website of Juliette Tariel-Adam
text:
üôÇ Hi there, thanks for visiting my personal website.
üêü I am an early-career researcher interested in how fish and other marine organisms evolve and behave.
üëÄ I am looking for a new postdoctoral position focused on fish behaviour and cognition, ideally working on behavioural traditions of coral reef fish. Feel free to contact me to connect.
üìç I currently hold an honorary postdoctoral position at Macquarie University. I work on a project about fishes that use tools remotely from France. You can find all my ongoing and past projects here.
‚ú® I‚Äôm also involved in the scientific society SORTEE, where I serve on the Board of Directors, the Conference Committee, and the DEI Committee. See my commitments here towards a science that is respectful and caring to all humans and living beings.

title: JTA‚Äôs commitments
text:
‚ÄúIn the end, we will conserve only what we love, we will love only what we understand, and we will understand only what we are taught.‚Äù Baba Dioum at the General Assembly of the IUCN held in New Delhi in 1968.
I would like to help ensure that the scientific community creates reliable and accessible knowledge that benefits all living beings. You can find my contributions toward this goal below.

title: JTA‚Äôs commitments
text:
Footnotes


What is Open Science? Open science involves many initiatives and practices that aim at make scientific results reliable, available for everyone and beneficial for humanity, while opening the process of scientific creation to everyone. You can find a nice description of what is open science by the UNESCO here.‚Ü©Ô∏é
What is SORTEE? SORTEE is not just a scientific society ‚Äì it is an inspiring community full of motivated and knowledgeable people. I highly recommend joining, regardless of your career stage or experience with open science. As a member, you will gain access to an active Slack channel for support, information on open science initiatives and job opportunities, free events like conferences, code clubs, workshops, seminars, and networking opportunities to find collaborators.‚Ü©Ô∏é
What is the Peer Community Journal? The Peer Community Journal (PCJ) is the journal of the Peer Community In (PCI) initiative. PCI seeks to address issues in the current publication system by creating communities in different fields to review and recommend preprints. This aims to free researchers from reliance on commercial publishers and promotes evaluating their work based on quality rather than metrics. Each PCI recommendation includes a short paragraph explaining the importance and quality of the publication, making it easier to assess a researcher‚Äôs work by reading these recommendations instead of looking at their h-index or citation counts.‚Ü©Ô∏é
What is DEI? Diversity, Equity and Inclusion involves many initiatives and practices that aim at creating an environment where everyone feel safe, welcomed, respected and valued and get the same opportunities to participate in the scientific process.‚Ü©Ô∏é
Keeping marine fish in aquariums is challenging, and sourcing these fish can be problematic. I wanted to avoid collecting fish from the reef or dying in the lab for my research. During my field observations, fish participated in the experiments willingly, so I didn‚Äôt need to catch them. Unfortunately, I did have to catch and sacrifice ghost crabs as part of my experiments to use them as food for fish. However, there was no waste ‚Äì every crab I caught was consumed by fish. Wrasses love eating crabs!‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text: Refer to the complete publication list here.

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
üêü Data collection

Fish behaviour in the wild: Designed and implemented experiments to observe fish behaviour in the field using scuba diving, snorkelling and live or remote video recordings. Analysed videos manually or using Boris software.
Marine fieldwork organisation: Planned and led two field trips involving scuba diving and snorkelling in Australia. Responsibilities included securing funding, obtaining permits and ethics approval, risk assessments, team training, and field logistics.
Fish behaviour in the lab: Designed and set up laboratory experiments to video-record fish behaviour (such as tool use, personality, mate choice). Analysed videos manually or with automatic position tracking on R.
Community science: Developed a campaign to collect data and raise awareness about fish tool use, which included creating a questionnaire, coding a website in CSS and HTML, developing an email sending strategy and creating social media posts.
Snail behaviour and morphology in the lab: Reared Physa acuta snails with or without odours of predators in the lab and assessed their anti-predator defences (morphology and behaviour). Analysed their morphology using ImageJ or the Momocs R package.
Microsatellite sequencing: Performed DNA extraction, PCR and peak assignment on Geneious.
RAD sequencing: Performed DNA extraction and library preparation for Illumina sequencing.

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
üîé Data analysis
I believe data analysis is my favourite part of the research process. I completed all statistical analyses in my projects and got involved in two projects to help with data analysis (ending up in two publications: Clark-Shen et al.¬†2024 and Lo√©va et al.¬†2025). I have also taught data analysis.

Data wrangling using R and the tidyverse R package
Linear models in R including generalised and mixed models
Complex random effect structure modelling of linear models using frequentist and Bayesian approaches in R to model behavioural individuality and plasticity
Principal Component Analysis in R
Survival analysis in R
Quantitative genetics
Parentage analysis with the software Colony
Genetic structure analysis with the software Genetix

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
üíª Data management

Version control using git
Code and data sharing: Prepared datasets, data dictionaries, annotated codes and licences following FAIR principles. Shared them on GitHub, Zenodo or OSF.
Reproducible workflow: Created clear folder structures within R projects, used renv for dependency management, automated data processing and figure generation, annotated code.

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
ü§óÔ∏è Result Sharing and Outreach

Conference organisation: Chair of the SORTEE conference committee in 2025, overseeing the successful organisation of their virtual conference on open science. Served as the program manager of the SORTEE conference committee in 2023 and 2024.
Social media engagement: Developed a social media campaign for the fish tool use project. Produced engaging posts and reels for Instagram using Adobe Premiere Pro.
Press release writing: Wrote two press releases and followed a 2-day science communitication online workshop.
Popular science communication: Interviewed for a Canadian radio. Reached the semi-finals of the 2023 FameLab competition, which included a one-day online training in science communication.
Popular science writing: Authored two popular science articles in French about my PhD project (article 1 and article 2).
Academic communication:

Collaborative paper writing: Managed collaborative writing with multiple authors.
Document writing and editing: Wrote manuscripts on LateX, Word or Google Docs.
Oral and poster presentation at scientific conferences. Used powerpoint (oral presentation) or Adobe Illustrator (poster). See all my conference contributions here.
Scientific figure creation: I believe figure creation is the my second favourite part of the research process, after data analysis! I use Adobe Illustrator, Inkscape and the ggplot2 R package.

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
Other academic skills

Teaching. See full list of teaching activities here.
Student supervision.

Supervised 2 graduate and 2 undergraduate students in media and communication, 1 undergraduate in education for the fish tool use project: Wayne Inchiparambil, Faria Awais, Anietta Susane Samuel, Simran Wadhwa, Nicole Romanos.
Co-supervised 5 graduate and 1 undergraduate biology students: Cyndi-Lee Harrison-Burgess,Lo√©va Martin-Podevin, Alice Fontaine, Ana√Øs Arzel, Estelle Champion, Delia Ben Sussan.
Attended a half-day workshop ‚ÄòGiving effective feedback‚Äô co-organised by Hugh Kearns and Macquarie University.
I would like to receive more supervision training in my next position.

Science editing: Performed final editing and reference review of manuscripts using Word and LaTeX for Peer Community Journal in 2023 and 2024.
Grant writing: See the list of awarded grants here.
Peer-review. Full peer-review record available on my ORCID profile.
Literature search and review, reference management using Zotero: Wrote a literature review on my PhD project and postdoc project.
Project management: Managed a scientific project from designing and securing funding to sharing the results.

title: JTA‚Äôs CV
text:
Other personal and interpersonal skills

Teamwork and collaboration: Worked both in person and remotely with international teams.
Team management. Coordinated team of 3-4 people for lab experiments and fieldwork.
Fluent in English and French
International relations
Self-motivation and management
Adaptation to change and flexibility: Completed four research internships, one PhD and one postdoc, all of which in different labs and 4 different countries
Problem solving and creative thinking: Academic research requires daily problem-solving and the ability to address unexpected challenges.
Attention to detail: Research work demands meticulous attention to detail to minimise errors and ensure accurate findings
